Lec23

\section{VII.B Canonical Formulation}

Using the states constructed in the previous section, we can calculate the canonical density matrix for non-interacting identical particles. In the coordinate representation we have

⟨{x⃗′}∣ρ∣{x⃗}⟩η=∑{k⃗}′∑P,P′ηPηP′⟨{x⃗′}∣P′{k⃗}⟩ρ({k⃗})⟨P{k⃗}∣{x⃗}⟩1Nη\left\langle\left\{\vec{x}^{\prime}\right\}|\rho|\{\vec{x}\}\right\rangle_{\eta}=\sum_{\{\vec{k}\}}^{\prime} \sum_{P, P^{\prime}} \eta^{P} \eta^{P^{\prime}}\left\langle\left\{\vec{x}^{\prime}\right\} \mid P^{\prime}\{\vec{k}\}\right\rangle \rho(\{\vec{k}\})\langle P\{\vec{k}\} \mid\{\vec{x}\}\rangle \frac{1}{N_{\eta}}⟨{x′}∣ρ∣{x}⟩η​={k}∑′​P,P′∑​ηPηP′⟨{x′}∣P′{k}⟩ρ({k})⟨P{k}∣{x}⟩Nη​1​

where ρ({k⃗})=exp⁡[−β(∑α=1Nℏ2kα2/2m)]/ZN.\rho(\{\vec{k}\})=\exp \left[-\beta\left(\sum_{\alpha=1}^{N} \hbar^{2} k_{\alpha}^{2} / 2 m\right)\right] / Z_{N} .ρ({k})=exp[−β(∑α=1N​ℏ2kα2​/2m)]/ZN​. The sum, ∑{k⃗1,k⃗2,⋯ ,k⃗N}′\sum_{\left\{\vec{k}_{1}, \vec{k}_{2}, \cdots, \vec{k}_{N}\right\}}^{\prime}∑{k1​,k2​,⋯,kN​}′​, is restricted to ensure that each identical particle state appears once and only once. In both the bosonic and fermionic subspaces, the set of occupation numbers {nk⃗}\left\{n_{\vec{k}}\right\}{nk​} uniquely identify a state. We can, however, remove this restriction from eq.(VII.11), if we divide by the resulting over-counting factor (for bosons) of N!/(∏k⃗nk⃗!)N ! /\left(\prod_{\vec{k}} n_{\vec{k}} !\right)N!/(∏k​nk​!), i.e.,

∑{k⃗}′=∑{k⃗}∏k⃗nk⃗!N!\sum_{\{\vec{k}\}}^{\prime}=\sum_{\{\vec{k}\}} \frac{\prod_{\vec{k}} n_{\vec{k}} !}{N !}{k}∑′​={k}∑​N!∏k​nk​!​

(Note that for fermions, the (−1)P(-1)^{P}(−1)P factors cancel out the contributions from cases where any nk⃗n_{\vec{k}}nk​ is larger than one.) Therefore,

⟨{x⃗′}∣ρ∣{x⃗}⟩=∑{k⃗}∏k⃗nk⃗!N!⋅1N!∏k⃗nk⃗!∑P,P′ηPηP′ZNexp⁡(−β∑α=1Nℏ2kα22m)⟨{x⃗′}∣P′{k⃗}⟩⟨P{k⃗}∣{x⃗}⟩\begin{aligned} \left\langle\left\{\vec{x}^{\prime}\right\}|\rho|\{\vec{x}\}\right\rangle=& \sum_{\{\vec{k}\}} \frac{\prod_{\vec{k}} n_{\vec{k}} !}{N !} \cdot \frac{1}{N ! \prod_{\vec{k}} n_{\vec{k}} !} \\ & \sum_{P, P^{\prime}} \frac{\eta^{P} \eta^{P^{\prime}}}{Z_{N}} \exp \left(-\beta \sum_{\alpha=1}^{N} \frac{\hbar^{2} k_{\alpha}^{2}}{2 m}\right)\left\langle\left\{\vec{x}^{\prime}\right\} \mid P^{\prime}\{\vec{k}\}\right\rangle\langle P\{\vec{k}\} \mid\{\vec{x}\}\rangle \end{aligned}⟨{x′}∣ρ∣{x}⟩=​{k}∑​N!∏k​nk​!​⋅N!∏k​nk​!1​P,P′∑​ZN​ηPηP′​exp(−βα=1∑N​2mℏ2kα2​​)⟨{x′}∣P′{k}⟩⟨P{k}∣{x}⟩​

In the limit of large volume, the sums over {k⃗}\{\vec{k}\}{k} can be replaced by integrals, and using the plane wave representation of wavefunctions, we have

⟨{x⃗′}∣ρ∣{x⃗}⟩=1ZN(N!)2∑P,P′ηPηP′∫∏α=1NVd3k⃗α(2π)3exp⁡(−βℏ2kα22m)×{exp⁡[−i∑α=1N(k⃗Pα⋅x⃗α−k⃗P′α⋅x⃗α′)]VN}\begin{aligned} \left\langle\left\{\vec{x}^{\prime}\right\}|\rho|\{\vec{x}\}\right\rangle=& \frac{1}{Z_{N}(N !)^{2}} \sum_{P, P^{\prime}} \eta^{P} \eta^{P^{\prime}} \int \prod_{\alpha=1}^{N} \frac{V d^{3} \vec{k}_{\alpha}}{(2 \pi)^{3}} \exp \left(-\frac{\beta \hbar^{2} k_{\alpha}^{2}}{2 m}\right) \\ & \times\left\{\frac{\exp \left[-i \sum_{\alpha=1}^{N}\left(\vec{k}_{P \alpha} \cdot \vec{x}_{\alpha}-\vec{k}_{P^{\prime} \alpha} \cdot \vec{x}_{\alpha}^{\prime}\right)\right]}{V^{N}}\right\} \end{aligned}⟨{x′}∣ρ∣{x}⟩=​ZN​(N!)21​P,P′∑​ηPηP′∫α=1∏N​(2π)3Vd3kα​​exp(−2mβℏ2kα2​​)×⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​VNexp[−i∑α=1N​(kPα​⋅xα​−kP′α​⋅xα′​)]​⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​​

We can order the sum in the exponent by focusing on a particular k⃗\vec{k}k -vector. Since ∑αf(Pα)g(α)=∑βf(β)g(P−1β)\sum_{\alpha} f(P \alpha) g(\alpha)=\sum_{\beta} f(\beta) g\left(P^{-1} \beta\right)∑α​f(Pα)g(α)=∑β​f(β)g(P−1β), where β=Pα\beta=P \alphaβ=Pα and α=P−1β\alpha=P^{-1} \betaα=P−1β, we obtain

⟨{x⃗′}∣ρ∣{x⃗}⟩=1ZN(N!)2∑P,P′ηPηP′∏α=1N[∫d3k⃗α(2π)3e−ik⃗α⋅(x⃗P−1α−x⃗P′−1′)−βℏ2kα2/2m]\left.\left\langle\left\{\vec{x}^{\prime}\right\}|\rho|\{\vec{x}\}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{Z_{N}(N !)^{2}} \sum_{P, P^{\prime}} \eta^{P} \eta^{P^{\prime}} \prod_{\alpha=1}^{N}\left[\int \frac{d^{3} \vec{k}_{\alpha}}{(2 \pi)^{3}} e^{-i \vec{k}_{\alpha} \cdot\left(\vec{x}_{P^{-1} \alpha}-\vec{x}_{P^{\prime}-1}^{\prime}\right.}\right)-\beta \hbar^{2} k_{\alpha}^{2} / 2 m\right]⟨{x′}∣ρ∣{x}⟩=ZN​(N!)21​P,P′∑​ηPηP′α=1∏N​[∫(2π)3d3kα​​e−ikα​⋅(xP−1α​−xP′−1′​)−βℏ2kα2​/2m⎦⎥⎤​

The gaussian integrals in the square brackets are equal to

1λ3exp⁡[−πλ2(x⃗P−1α−x⃗P′−1′)2]\frac{1}{\lambda^{3}} \exp \left[-\frac{\pi}{\lambda^{2}}\left(\vec{x}_{P-1} \alpha-\vec{x}_{P^{\prime}-1}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right]λ31​exp[−λ2π​(xP−1​α−xP′−1′​)2]

Setting β=P−1α\beta=P^{-1} \alphaβ=P−1α in eq.(VII.14) gives

⟨{x⃗′}∣ρ∣{x⃗}⟩=1ZNλ3N(N!)2∑P,P′ηPηP′exp⁡[−πλ2∑β=1N(x⃗β−x⃗P′−1′)2]\left\langle\left\{\vec{x}^{\prime}\right\}|\rho|\{\vec{x}\}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{Z_{N} \lambda^{3 N}(N !)^{2}} \sum_{P, P^{\prime}} \eta^{P} \eta^{P^{\prime}} \exp \left[-\frac{\pi}{\lambda^{2}} \sum_{\beta=1}^{N}\left(\vec{x}_{\beta}-\vec{x}_{P^{\prime}-1}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right]⟨{x′}∣ρ∣{x}⟩=ZN​λ3N(N!)21​P,P′∑​ηPηP′exp⎣⎢⎡​−λ2π​β=1∑N​(xβ​−xP′−1′​)2⎦⎥⎤​

Finally, we set Q=P′−1PQ=P^{\prime-1} PQ=P′−1P, and use the results ηP=ηP−1\eta^{P}=\eta^{P^{-1}}ηP=ηP−1, and ηQ=ηP′−1P=ηP′ηP\eta^{Q}=\eta^{P^{\prime-1} P}=\eta^{P^{\prime}} \eta^{P}ηQ=ηP′−1P=ηP′ηP, to get (after performing ∑P=N!)\left.\sum_{P}=N !\right)∑P​=N!)

⟨{x⃗′}∣ρ∣{x⃗}⟩=1ZNλ3NN!∑QηQexp⁡[−πλ2∑β=1N(x⃗β−x⃗Qβ′)2]\left\langle\left\{\vec{x}^{\prime}\right\}|\rho|\{\vec{x}\}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{Z_{N} \lambda^{3 N} N !} \sum_{Q} \eta^{Q} \exp \left[-\frac{\pi}{\lambda^{2}} \sum_{\beta=1}^{N}\left(\vec{x}_{\beta}-\vec{x}_{Q \beta}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right]⟨{x′}∣ρ∣{x}⟩=ZN​λ3NN!1​Q∑​ηQexp⎣⎢⎡​−λ2π​β=1∑N​(xβ​−xQβ′​)2⎦⎥⎤​

The canonical partition function, ZNZ_{N}ZN​, is obtained from the normalization condition

tr⁡(ρ)=1,⟹∫∏α=1Nd3x⃗α⟨{x⃗}∣ρ∣{x⃗}⟩=1\operatorname{tr}(\rho)=1, \quad \Longrightarrow \quad \int \prod_{\alpha=1}^{N} d^{3} \vec{x}_{\alpha}\langle\{\vec{x}\}|\rho|\{\vec{x}\}\rangle=1tr(ρ)=1,⟹∫α=1∏N​d3xα​⟨{x}∣ρ∣{x}⟩=1

as

ZN=1N!λ3N∫∏α=1Nd3x⃗α∑QηQexp⁡[−πλ2∑β=1N(x⃗β−x⃗Qβ)2]Z_{N}=\frac{1}{N ! \lambda^{3 N}} \int \prod_{\alpha=1}^{N} d^{3} \vec{x}_{\alpha} \sum_{Q} \eta^{Q} \exp \left[-\frac{\pi}{\lambda^{2}} \sum_{\beta=1}^{N}\left(\vec{x}_{\beta}-\vec{x}_{Q \beta}\right)^{2}\right]ZN​=N!λ3N1​∫α=1∏N​d3xα​Q∑​ηQexp⎣⎢⎡​−λ2π​β=1∑N​(xβ​−xQβ​)2⎦⎥⎤​

The quantum partition function thus involves a sum over N!N !N! possible permutations. The classical result ZN=(V/λ3)N/N!Z_{N}=\left(V / \lambda^{3}\right)^{N} / N !ZN​=(V/λ3)N/N!, is obtained from the term corresponding to no particle exchange, Q≡1.Q \equiv 1 .Q≡1. The division by N!N !N! finally justifies the factor that was (somewhat artificially) introduces in classical statistical mechanics to deal with the phase space of identical particles. However, this classical result is only valid at very high temperature and is modified by the quantum corrections coming from the remaining permutations. As any permutation involves a product of factors exp⁡[−π(x⃗1−x⃗2)2/λ2]\exp \left[-\pi\left(\vec{x}_{1}-\vec{x}_{2}\right)^{2} / \lambda^{2}\right]exp[−π(x1​−x2​)2/λ2], its contributions vanishes as λ→0\lambda \rightarrow 0λ→0 for T→∞T \rightarrow \inftyT→∞

The lowest order correction comes from the simplest permutation which is the exchange of two particles. The exchange of particles 1 and 2 is accompanied by a factor of ηexp⁡[−2π(x⃗1−x⃗2)2/λ2].\eta \exp \left[-2 \pi\left(\vec{x}_{1}-\vec{x}_{2}\right)^{2} / \lambda^{2}\right] .ηexp[−2π(x1​−x2​)2/λ2]. As each of the possible N(N−1)/2N(N-1) / 2N(N−1)/2 pairwise exchanges gives the same contribution to ZNZ_{N}ZN​, we get

ZN=1N!λ3N∫∏α=1Nd3x⃗α{1+N(N−1)2ηexp⁡[−2πλ2(x⃗1−x⃗2)2]+⋯ }Z_{N}=\frac{1}{N ! \lambda^{3 N}} \int \prod_{\alpha=1}^{N} d^{3} \vec{x}_{\alpha}\left\{1+\frac{N(N-1)}{2} \eta \exp \left[-\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda^{2}}\left(\vec{x}_{1}-\vec{x}_{2}\right)^{2}\right]+\cdots\right\}ZN​=N!λ3N1​∫α=1∏N​d3xα​{1+2N(N−1)​ηexp[−λ22π​(x1​−x2​)2]+⋯}

For any α≥2,∫d3x⃗α=V;\alpha \geq 2, \int d^{3} \vec{x}_{\alpha}=V ;α≥2,∫d3xα​=V; in the remaining two integrations we can use the relative, r⃗12=x⃗2−x⃗1\vec{r}_{12}=\vec{x}_{2}-\vec{x}_{1}r12​=x2​−x1​, and center of mass coordinates to get

ZN=1N!λ3NVN[1+N(N−1)2Vη∫d3r⃗12e−2πr⃗122/λ2+⋯ ]=1N!(Vλ3)N[1+N(N−1)2V⋅(2πλ24π)3η+⋯ ]\begin{aligned} Z_{N} &=\frac{1}{N ! \lambda^{3 N}} V^{N}\left[1+\frac{N(N-1)}{2 V} \eta \int d^{3} \vec{r}_{12} e^{-2 \pi \vec{r}_{12}^{2} / \lambda^{2}}+\cdots\right] \\ &=\frac{1}{N !}\left(\frac{V}{\lambda^{3}}\right)^{N}\left[1+\frac{N(N-1)}{2 V} \cdot\left(\sqrt{\frac{2 \pi \lambda^{2}}{4 \pi}}\right)^{3} \eta+\cdots\right] \end{aligned}ZN​​=N!λ3N1​VN[1+2VN(N−1)​η∫d3r12​e−2πr122​/λ2+⋯]=N!1​(λ3V​)N⎣⎢⎡​1+2VN(N−1)​⋅(4π2πλ2​​)3η+⋯⎦⎥⎤​​

From the corresponding free energy,

F=−kBTln⁡ZN=−NkBTln⁡[eλ3⋅VN]−kBTN22V⋅λ323/2η+⋯F=-k_{B} T \ln Z_{N}=-N k_{B} T \ln \left[\frac{e}{\lambda^{3}} \cdot \frac{V}{N}\right]-\frac{k_{B} T N^{2}}{2 V} \cdot \frac{\lambda^{3}}{2^{3 / 2}} \eta+\cdotsF=−kB​TlnZN​=−NkB​Tln[λ3e​⋅NV​]−2VkB​TN2​⋅23/2λ3​η+⋯

the gas pressure is computed as

P=−∂F∂V∣T=NkBTV−N2kBTV2⋅λ325/2η+⋯=nkBT[1−ηλ325/2n+⋯ ]P=-\left.\frac{\partial F}{\partial V}\right|_{T}=\frac{N k_{B} T}{V}-\frac{N^{2} k_{B} T}{V^{2}} \cdot \frac{\lambda^{3}}{2^{5 / 2}} \eta+\cdots=n k_{B} T\left[1-\frac{\eta \lambda^{3}}{2^{5 / 2}} n+\cdots\right]P=−∂V∂F​∣∣∣∣∣​T​=VNkB​T​−V2N2kB​T​⋅25/2λ3​η+⋯=nkB​T[1−25/2ηλ3​n+⋯]

Note that the first quantum correction is equivalent to a second virial coefficient of

B2=−ηλ325/2B_{2}=-\frac{\eta \lambda^{3}}{2^{5 / 2}}B2​=−25/2ηλ3​

The resulting correction to pressure is negative for bosons, and positive for fermions. In the classical formulation, a second virial coefficient was obtained from a two-body interaction. The classical potential V(r⃗)\mathcal{V}(\vec{r})V(r) that leads to the second virial coefficient in eq.(VII.22) is obtained from

f(r⃗)=e−βV(r⃗)−1=ηe−2πr⃗2/λ2,⟹V(r⃗)=−kBTln⁡[1+ηe−2πr⃗2/λ2]≈−kBTηe−2πr⃗2/λ2\begin{aligned} &f(\vec{r})=e^{-\beta \mathcal{V}(\vec{r})}-1=\eta e^{-2 \pi \vec{r}^{2} / \lambda^{2}}, \quad \Longrightarrow \\ &\mathcal{V}(\vec{r})=-k_{B} T \ln \left[1+\eta e^{-2 \pi \vec{r}^{2} / \lambda^{2}}\right] \approx-k_{B} T \eta e^{-2 \pi \vec{r}^{2} / \lambda^{2}} \end{aligned}​f(r)=e−βV(r)−1=ηe−2πr2/λ2,⟹V(r)=−kB​Tln[1+ηe−2πr2/λ2]≈−kB​Tηe−2πr2/λ2​

(The final approximation corresponds to high temperatures, where only the first correction is important). Thus the effects of quantum statistics at high temperatures are approximately equivalent to introducing an interaction between particles. The interaction is attractive for bosons, repulsive for fermions, and operates over distances of the order of the thermal wavelength λ\lambdaλ.

\section{VII.C Grand Canonical Formulation}

Calculating the partition function by performing all the sums in eq.(VII.17) is a formidable task. Alternatively, we can compute ZNZ_{N}ZN​ in the energy basis as

ZN=tr⁡(e−βH)=∑{k⃗α}′exp⁡[−β∑α=1NE(k⃗α)]=∑{nk⃗}′exp⁡[−β∑k⃗E(k⃗)n(k⃗)]Z_{N}=\operatorname{tr}\left(e^{-\beta \mathcal{H}}\right)=\sum_{\left\{\vec{k}_{\alpha}\right\}}^{\prime} \exp \left[-\beta \sum_{\alpha=1}^{N} \mathcal{E}\left(\vec{k}_{\alpha}\right)\right]=\sum_{\left\{n_{\vec{k}}\right\}}^{\prime} \exp \left[-\beta \sum_{\vec{k}} \mathcal{E}(\vec{k}) n(\vec{k})\right]ZN​=tr(e−βH)={kα​}∑′​exp[−βα=1∑N​E(kα​)]={nk​}∑′​exp⎣⎢⎡​−βk∑​E(k)n(k)⎦⎥⎤​

These sums are still difficult to perform due to the restrictions of symmetry on the allowed values of k⃗\vec{k}k or {nk⃗}:\left\{n_{\vec{k}}\right\}:{nk​}: The occupation numbers {nk⃗}\left\{n_{\vec{k}}\right\}{nk​} are restricted to ∑k⃗nk⃗=N\sum_{\vec{k}} n_{\vec{k}}=N∑k​nk​=N, and nk⃗=0,1,2,⋯n_{\vec{k}}=0,1,2, \cdotsnk​=0,1,2,⋯ for bosons, while nk⃗=0n_{\vec{k}}=0nk​=0 or 1 for fermions. As usual, the first constraint can be removed by looking at the grand partition function,

Qη(T,μ)=∑N=0∞eβμN∑{nk⃗}′exp⁡[−β∑k⃗E(k⃗)nk⃗]=∑{nk⃗}∏k⃗exp⁡[−β(E(k⃗)−μ)nk⃗]\begin{aligned} \mathcal{Q}_{\eta}(T, \mu) &=\sum_{N=0}^{\infty} e^{\beta \mu N} \sum_{\left\{n_{\vec{k}}\right\}}^{\prime} \exp \left[-\beta \sum_{\vec{k}} \mathcal{E}(\vec{k}) n_{\vec{k}}\right] \\ &=\sum_{\left\{n_{\vec{k}}\right\}} \prod_{\vec{k}} \exp \left[-\beta(\mathcal{E}(\vec{k})-\mu) n_{\vec{k}}\right] \end{aligned}Qη​(T,μ)​=N=0∑∞​eβμN{nk​}∑′​exp⎣⎢⎡​−βk∑​E(k)nk​⎦⎥⎤​={nk​}∑​k∏​exp[−β(E(k)−μ)nk​]​

The sums over {nk⃗}\left\{n_{\vec{k}}\right\}{nk​} can now be performed independently for each k⃗\vec{k}k, subject to the restrictions on occupation numbers imposed by particle symmetry.

  • For fermions, nk⃗=0n_{\vec{k}}=0nk​=0 or 1, and
Q−=∏k⃗[1+exp⁡(βμ−βE(k⃗))]\mathcal{Q}_{-}=\prod_{\vec{k}}[1+\exp (\beta \mu-\beta \mathcal{E}(\vec{k}))]Q−​=k∏​[1+exp(βμ−βE(k))]
  • For bosons nk⃗=0,1,2,⋯n_{\vec{k}}=0,1,2, \cdotsnk​=0,1,2,⋯, and summing the geometric series gives
Q+=∏k⃗[1−exp⁡(βμ−βE(k⃗))]−1\mathcal{Q}_{+}=\prod_{\vec{k}}[1-\exp (\beta \mu-\beta \mathcal{E}(\vec{k}))]^{-1}Q+​=k∏​[1−exp(βμ−βE(k))]−1

The results for both cases can be presented simultaneously as

ln⁡Qη=−η∑k⃗ln⁡[1−ηexp⁡(βμ−βE(k⃗))]\ln \mathcal{Q}_{\eta}=-\eta \sum_{\vec{k}} \ln [1-\eta \exp (\beta \mu-\beta \mathcal{E}(\vec{k}))]lnQη​=−ηk∑​ln[1−ηexp(βμ−βE(k))]

with η=−1\eta=-1η=−1 for fermions, and η=+1\eta=+1η=+1 for bosons.

In the grand canonical formulation, different one-particle states are occupied independently, with a joint probability

pη({n(k⃗)})=1Qη∏k⃗exp⁡[−β(E(k⃗)−μ)nk⃗]p_{\eta}(\{n(\vec{k})\})=\frac{1}{\mathcal{Q}_{\eta}} \prod_{\vec{k}} \exp \left[-\beta(\mathcal{E}(\vec{k})-\mu) n_{\vec{k}}\right]pη​({n(k)})=Qη​1​k∏​exp[−β(E(k)−μ)nk​]

The average occupation number of a state of energy E(k⃗)\mathcal{E}(\vec{k})E(k) is given by

⟨nk⃗⟩η=−∂ln⁡Qη∂(βE(k⃗))=1z−1eβE(k⃗)−η\left\langle n_{\vec{k}}\right\rangle_{\eta}=-\frac{\partial \ln \mathcal{Q}_{\eta}}{\partial(\beta \mathcal{E}(\vec{k}))}=\frac{1}{z^{-1} e^{\beta \mathcal{E}(\vec{k})}-\eta}⟨nk​⟩η​=−∂(βE(k))∂lnQη​​=z−1eβE(k)−η1​

where z=exp⁡(βμ)z=\exp (\beta \mu)z=exp(βμ). The average values of the particle number and internal energy are then given by

{Nη=∑k⃗⟨nk⃗⟩η=∑k⃗1z−1eβE(k⃗)−ηEη=∑k⃗E(k⃗)⟨nk⃗⟩η=∑k⃗E(k⃗)z−1eβE(k⃗)−η\left\{\begin{array}{l} N_{\eta}=\sum_{\vec{k}}\left\langle n_{\vec{k}}\right\rangle_{\eta}=\sum_{\vec{k}} \frac{1}{z^{-1} e^{\beta \mathcal{E}(\vec{k})}-\eta} \\ E_{\eta}=\sum_{\vec{k}} \mathcal{E}(\vec{k})\left\langle n_{\vec{k}}\right\rangle_{\eta}=\sum_{\vec{k}} \frac{\mathcal{E}(\vec{k})}{z^{-1} e^{\beta \mathcal{E}(\vec{k})}-\eta} \end{array}\right.{Nη​=∑k​⟨nk​⟩η​=∑k​z−1eβE(k)−η1​Eη​=∑k​E(k)⟨nk​⟩η​=∑k​z−1eβE(k)−ηE(k)​​

\section{VII.D Non-relativistic Gas}

Quantum particles are further characterized by a spin s. In the absence of a magnetic field different spin states have the same energy, and a spin degeneracy factor, g=2s+1g=2 s+1g=2s+1, multiplies eqs.(VII.28)-(VII.31). In particular, for a non-relativistic gas in three dimensions (E(k⃗)=ℏ2k2/2m\left(\mathcal{E}(\vec{k})=\hbar^{2} k^{2} / 2 m\right.(E(k)=ℏ2k2/2m, and ∑k⃗→V∫d3k⃗/(2π)3)\left.\sum_{\vec{k}} \rightarrow V \int d^{3} \vec{k} /(2 \pi)^{3}\right)∑k​→V∫d3k/(2π)3) these equations reduce to

{βPη=ln⁡QηV=ηg∫d3k⃗(2π)3ln⁡[1−ηzexp⁡(−βℏ2k22m)]nη≡NηV=g∫d3k⃗(2π)31z−1exp⁡(βℏ2k22m)−ηεη≡EηV=g∫d3k⃗(2π)3ℏ2k22m1z−1exp⁡(βℏ2k22m)−η\left\{\begin{array}{l} \beta P_{\eta}=\frac{\ln \mathcal{Q}_{\eta}}{V}=\eta g \int \frac{d^{3} \vec{k}}{(2 \pi)^{3}} \ln \left[1-\eta z \exp \left(-\frac{\beta \hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}\right)\right] \\ n_{\eta} \equiv \frac{N_{\eta}}{V}=g \int \frac{d^{3} \vec{k}}{(2 \pi)^{3}} \frac{1}{z^{-1} \exp \left(\frac{\beta \hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}\right)-\eta} \\ \varepsilon_{\eta} \equiv \frac{E_{\eta}}{V}=g \int \frac{d^{3} \vec{k}}{(2 \pi)^{3}} \frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m} \frac{1}{z^{-1} \exp \left(\frac{\beta \hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}\right)-\eta} \end{array}\right.⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​βPη​=VlnQη​​=ηg∫(2π)3d3k​ln[1−ηzexp(−2mβℏ2k2​)]nη​≡VNη​​=g∫(2π)3d3k​z−1exp(2mβℏ2k2​)−η1​εη​≡VEη​​=g∫(2π)3d3k​2mℏ2k2​z−1exp(2mβℏ2k2​)−η1​​

To simplify these equations, we change variables to x=βℏ2k2/(2m)x=\beta \hbar^{2} k^{2} /(2 m)x=βℏ2k2/(2m), so that

k=2mkBTℏx1/2=2π1/2λx1/2,⟹dk=π1/2λx−1/2dxk=\frac{\sqrt{2 m k_{B} T}}{\hbar} x^{1 / 2}=\frac{2 \pi^{1 / 2}}{\lambda} x^{1 / 2}, \quad \Longrightarrow \quad d k=\frac{\pi^{1 / 2}}{\lambda} x^{-1 / 2} d xk=ℏ2mkB​T​​x1/2=λ2π1/2​x1/2,⟹dk=λπ1/2​x−1/2dx

Substituting into eqs.(VII.32) gives

{βPη=−ηg2π24π3/2λ3∫0∞dxx1/2ln⁡(1−ηze−x)=gλ343π∫0∞dxx3/2z−1ex−η, (integration by parts) nη=gλ32π∫0∞dxx1/2z−1ex−ηβεη=gλ32π∫0∞dxx3/2z−1ex−η\left\{\begin{aligned} \beta P_{\eta}=&-\eta \frac{g}{2 \pi^{2}} \frac{4 \pi^{3 / 2}}{\lambda^{3}} \int_{0}^{\infty} d x x^{1 / 2} \ln \left(1-\eta z e^{-x}\right) \\ &=\frac{g}{\lambda^{3}} \frac{4}{3 \sqrt{\pi}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d x x^{3 / 2}}{z^{-1} e^{x}-\eta}, \quad \text { (integration by parts) } \\ n_{\eta}=& \frac{g}{\lambda^{3}} \frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d x x^{1 / 2}}{z^{-1} e^{x}-\eta} \\ \beta \varepsilon_{\eta}=& \frac{g}{\lambda^{3}} \frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d x x^{3 / 2}}{z^{-1} e^{x}-\eta} \end{aligned}\right.⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​βPη​=nη​=βεη​=​−η2π2g​λ34π3/2​∫0∞​dxx1/2ln(1−ηze−x)=λ3g​3π​4​∫0∞​z−1ex−ηdxx3/2​, (integration by parts) λ3g​π​2​∫0∞​z−1ex−ηdxx1/2​λ3g​π​2​∫0∞​z−1ex−ηdxx3/2​​

We now define two sets of functions by

fmη(z)=1(m−1)!∫0∞dxxm−1z−1ex−ηf_{m}^{\eta}(z)=\frac{1}{(m-1) !} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d x x^{m-1}}{z^{-1} e^{x}-\eta}fmη​(z)=(m−1)!1​∫0∞​z−1ex−ηdxxm−1​

For non-integer arguments, the function m!≡Γ(m+1)m ! \equiv \Gamma(m+1)m!≡Γ(m+1) is defined by the integral ∫0∞dxxme−x.\int_{0}^{\infty} d x x^{m} e^{-x} . \quad∫0∞​dxxme−x. In particular, from this definition it follows that (1/2)!=π/2(1 / 2) !=\sqrt{\pi} / 2(1/2)!=π​/2, and (3/2)!=(3/2)π/2.(3 / 2) !=(3 / 2) \sqrt{\pi} / 2 .(3/2)!=(3/2)π​/2. Eqs.(VII.33) now take the simple form

{βPη=gλ3f5/2η(z)nη=gλ3f3/2η(z)εη=32Pη\left\{\begin{aligned} \beta P_{\eta} &=\frac{g}{\lambda^{3}} f_{5 / 2}^{\eta}(z) \\ n_{\eta} &=\frac{g}{\lambda^{3}} f_{3 / 2}^{\eta}(z) \\ \varepsilon_{\eta} &=\frac{3}{2} P_{\eta} \end{aligned}\right.⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​βPη​nη​εη​​=λ3g​f5/2η​(z)=λ3g​f3/2η​(z)=23​Pη​​

These results completely describe the thermodynamics of ideal quantum gases as a function of zzz. To find the equation of state Pη(nη,T)P_{\eta}\left(n_{\eta}, T\right)Pη​(nη​,T), we need to solve for zzz in terms of density. This requires knowledge of the behavior of the functions fmη(z)f_{m}^{\eta}(z)fmη​(z).

The high temperature, low density (non-degenerate) limit will be examined first. In this limit, zzz is small, and

fmη(z)=1(m−1)!∫0∞dxxm−1z−1ex−η=1(m−1)!∫0∞dxxm−1(ze−x)(1−ηze−x)−1=1(m−1)!∫0∞dxxm−1∑α=1∞(ze−x)αηα+1=∑α=1∞ηα+1zα1(m−1)!∫0∞dxxm−1e−αx=∑α=1∞ηα+1zααm=z+ηz22m+z33m+ηz44m+⋯\begin{aligned} f_{m}^{\eta}(z) &=\frac{1}{(m-1) !} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d x x^{m-1}}{z^{-1} e^{x}-\eta}=\frac{1}{(m-1) !} \int_{0}^{\infty} d x x^{m-1}\left(z e^{-x}\right)\left(1-\eta z e^{-x}\right)^{-1} \\ &=\frac{1}{(m-1) !} \int_{0}^{\infty} d x x^{m-1} \sum_{\alpha=1}^{\infty}\left(z e^{-x}\right)^{\alpha} \eta^{\alpha+1} \\ &=\sum_{\alpha=1}^{\infty} \eta^{\alpha+1} z^{\alpha} \frac{1}{(m-1) !} \int_{0}^{\infty} d x x^{m-1} e^{-\alpha x} \\ &=\sum_{\alpha=1}^{\infty} \eta^{\alpha+1} \frac{z^{\alpha}}{\alpha^{m}}=z+\eta \frac{z^{2}}{2^{m}}+\frac{z^{3}}{3^{m}}+\eta \frac{z^{4}}{4^{m}}+\cdots \end{aligned}fmη​(z)​=(m−1)!1​∫0∞​z−1ex−ηdxxm−1​=(m−1)!1​∫0∞​dxxm−1(ze−x)(1−ηze−x)−1=(m−1)!1​∫0∞​dxxm−1α=1∑∞​(ze−x)αηα+1=α=1∑∞​ηα+1zα(m−1)!1​∫0∞​dxxm−1e−αx=α=1∑∞​ηα+1αmzα​=z+η2mz2​+3mz3​+η4mz4​+⋯​

We thus find (self-consistently) that fmη(z)f_{m}^{\eta}(z)fmη​(z), and hence nη(z)n_{\eta}(z)nη​(z) and Pη(z)P_{\eta}(z)Pη​(z), are indeed small as z→0z \rightarrow 0z→0. Eqs.(VII.35) in this limit give,

{nηλ3g=f3/2η(z)=z+ηz223/2+z333/2+ηz443/2+⋯βPηλ3g=f5/2η(z)=z+ηz225/2+z335/2+ηz445/2+⋯\left\{\begin{array}{c} \frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}=f_{3 / 2}^{\eta}(z)=z+\eta \frac{z^{2}}{2^{3 / 2}}+\frac{z^{3}}{3^{3 / 2}}+\eta \frac{z^{4}}{4^{3 / 2}}+\cdots \\ \frac{\beta P_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}=f_{5 / 2}^{\eta}(z)=z+\eta \frac{z^{2}}{2^{5 / 2}}+\frac{z^{3}}{3^{5 / 2}}+\eta \frac{z^{4}}{4^{5 / 2}}+\cdots \end{array}\right.{gnη​λ3​=f3/2η​(z)=z+η23/2z2​+33/2z3​+η43/2z4​+⋯gβPη​λ3​=f5/2η​(z)=z+η25/2z2​+35/2z3​+η45/2z4​+⋯​

The first of the above equations can be solved perturbatively, by the recursive procedure of substituting the solution up to a lower order, as

z=nηλ3g−ηz223/2−z333/2−⋯=(nηλ3g)−η23/2(nηλ3g)2−⋯=(nηλ3g)−η23/2(nηλ3g)2+(14−133/2)(nηλ3g)3−⋯\begin{aligned} z &=\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}-\eta \frac{z^{2}}{2^{3 / 2}}-\frac{z^{3}}{3^{3 / 2}}-\cdots \\ &=\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)-\frac{\eta}{2^{3 / 2}}\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)^{2}-\cdots \\ &=\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)-\frac{\eta}{2^{3 / 2}}\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{3^{3 / 2}}\right)\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)^{3}-\cdots \end{aligned}z​=gnη​λ3​−η23/2z2​−33/2z3​−⋯=(gnη​λ3​)−23/2η​(gnη​λ3​)2−⋯=(gnη​λ3​)−23/2η​(gnη​λ3​)2+(41​−33/21​)(gnη​λ3​)3−⋯​

Substituting this solution into the second leads to

βPηλ3g=(nηλ3g)−η23/2(nηλ3g)2+(14−133/2)(nηλ3g)3+η25/2(nηλ3g)2−18(nηλ3g)3+135/2(nηλ3g)3+⋯\begin{aligned} \frac{\beta P_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g} &=\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)-\frac{\eta}{2^{3 / 2}}\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{3^{3 / 2}}\right)\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)^{3} \\ &+\frac{\eta}{2^{5 / 2}}\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{8}\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)^{3}+\frac{1}{3^{5 / 2}}\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)^{3}+\cdots \end{aligned}gβPη​λ3​​=(gnη​λ3​)−23/2η​(gnη​λ3​)2+(41​−33/21​)(gnη​λ3​)3+25/2η​(gnη​λ3​)2−81​(gnη​λ3​)3+35/21​(gnη​λ3​)3+⋯​

The pressure of the quantum gas can thus be obtained from the virial expansion,

Pη=nηkBT[1−η25/2(nηλ3g)+(18−235/2)(nηλ3g)2+⋯ ]P_{\eta}=n_{\eta} k_{B} T\left[1-\frac{\eta}{2^{5 / 2}}\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{8}-\frac{2}{3^{5 / 2}}\right)\left(\frac{n_{\eta} \lambda^{3}}{g}\right)^{2}+\cdots\right]Pη​=nη​kB​T[1−25/2η​(gnη​λ3​)+(81​−35/22​)(gnη​λ3​)2+⋯]

The second virial coefficient B2=−ηλ3/(25/2g)B_{2}=-\eta \lambda^{3} /\left(2^{5 / 2} g\right)B2​=−ηλ3/(25/2g), agrees with eq.(VII.22) computed in the canonical ensemble for g=1.g=1 .g=1. The natural (dimensionless) expansion parameter is nηλ3/gn_{\eta} \lambda^{3} / gnη​λ3/g, and quantum mechanical effects become important when nηλ3≥g;n_{\eta} \lambda^{3} \geq g ;nη​λ3≥g; the quantum degenerate limit. The behavior of fermi and bose gases is very different in this degenerate limit of low temperatures and high densities, and the two cases will be discussed separately in the following sections. MIT OpenCourseWare

http://ocw.mit.edu

\subsection{Statistical Mechanics I: Statistical Mechanics of Particles \ Fall 2013}

For information about citing these materials or our Terms of Use, visit: http://ocw.mit.edu/terms.

noteIndex.title: Introduction
noteIndex.body:
# Introduction to Tex Decks!

TexDeck.net is a collection of resources assembled to make LaTeX rich flashcards easier to write, remix, and organize.

The effect: Low cost active learning, allowing one's knowledge of science to scale sustainably.

A [[case study]] is in progress to seed the flashcard repository using a course in [nanoelectronics](https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-701-introduction-to-nanoelectronics-spring-2010/) from [OpenCourseWare](https://ocw.mit.edu/)

((ref:[[case study.1 motivation]]))

### How does the system work?

....

### Intellectual Property

All work is [CC-BY-SA 4.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/) unless otherwise specified at the top of a page. I cannot really enforce the attribution clause, but I do highly reccomend it. If you find these resources useful, consider sharing them with others.

Also, keep in mind that this is a work in progress and may contain errors. [Pull requests on these study resources](https://github.com/Stedag/ocwphy) are encouraged.

Despite accumulating a good deal of notes as part of my B.S. I will not include any of school notes among these resources to honor copyright agreements with my department. Nonetheless I forsee monotonic aggregation of resources organized around OCW classes or open-access textbooks.

For any concerns regarding IP, open an issue on github.
